metadata.title: Tungstate ion (WO<ce:inf loc=post>4</ce:inf><ce:sup loc=post>2-</ce:sup>) confined in hydrophilic/hydrophobic nanomaterials functionalized brönsted acidic ionic liquid as highly active catalyst in the selective aerobic oxidation of alcohols in water

Tungstate ion (WO4 2-) confined in hydrophilic/hydrophobic nanomaterials functionalized brönsted acidic ionic liquid as highly active catalyst in the selective aerobic oxidation of alcohols in water Fatemeh Rajabi a * Mostafa Nafe a Ghasem Rezanejad Bardajee a * Rafael Luque b c a Department of Science, Payame Noor University, 19395-4697, Tehran, Iran Department of Science Payame Noor University Tehran 19395-4697 Iran aDepartment of Science, Payame Noor University, 19395-4697, Tehran, Iran, e-mail: b Departamento de Química Orgánica, Universidad de Córdoba, Campus de Rabanales, Edificio Marie Curie (C-3), Ctra Nnal IV-A, Km 396, E14014, Cordoba, Spain Departamento de Química Orgánica Universidad de Córdoba Campus de Rabanales, Edificio Marie Curie (C-3) Ctra Nnal IV-A, Km 396 Cordoba E14014 Spain b Departamento de Química Orgánica, Universidad de Córdoba, Campus de Rabanales, Edificio Marie Curie (C-3), Ctra Nnal IV-A, Km 396, E14014, Cordoba, Spain. c Peoples Friendship University of Russia (RUDN University), 6 Miklukho-Maklaya Str., 117198, Moscow, Russia Peoples Friendship University of Russia (RUDN University) 6 Miklukho-Maklaya Str. Moscow 117198 Russia c Peoples Friendship University of Russia (RUDN University), 6 Miklukho-Maklaya Str., 117198, Moscow, Russia. ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract A Brönsted acidic Ionic Liquid containing tungstate anion functionalized polysiloxane network (PMO-IL-WO4 2 -) was synthesized by simple self-condensation of tungstic acid and zwitterionic organosilane precursor possessing both imidazolium and sulfonate groups. Characterization by scanning electron microscopy (SEM), Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), X-ray powder diffraction (XRD), thermal gravimetric analysis TGA, nitrogen porosimetry, solid-state NMR spectroscopy and elemental analysis confirmed that both imidazolium cation and tungstate anion of zwitterion are successfully incorporated inside the organosilica framework. The catalytic activity of resulting hybrid PMO-IL- WO4 2- material was studied in the selective aerobic oxidation of primary and secondary alcohols using an atmospheric pressure of air in pure water. Due to the ionic liquid-based charged surface containing hydrophilic sulfonic acid and tungstate group, the synergistic hydrophilic/hydrophobic and redox effect of PMO-IL-WO4 2 - as water-friendly catalyst facilitates and enhances the activity and selectivity toward the target oxidative products in water and proved to have a particularly broad substrate scope for reliable aerobic oxidation reaction. Furthermore, the catalyst showed outstanding stability and could be easily separated and reused at least ten reactions run under the same conditions as fresh catalyst without any loss of catalytic activity and product selectivity. Keywords tungstate ions PMO ionic liquidsaerobic oxidations alcohols Introduction Aldehydes and ketones play a prominent role in pharmaceutical and industrial process and significant research efforts has been put together via selective oxidation of alcohols [1–3]. In recent years, significant advances have been made for development of fundamentally new and environmentally benign catalytic systems for oxidation of alcohols with a high degree of selectivity [4–6]. From the stand point of green chemistry and sustainability, aerobic oxidation has widely provided the inspiration for a broad range of applications in pharmaceutical and chemical industries [7–9]. Molecular oxygen (O2), from air, is the cheapest, greenest and most eco-friendly chemical oxidant available [10,11]. As a result, it is an ideally attractive alternative to more toxic and expensive oxidizing traditional agents such as chromate and permanganate. Numerous reports involved homogeneously and heterogeneously catalyzed aerobic oxidation of alcohols to corresponding carbonyl compounds with molecular oxygen have been appeared in literature over the years [12–19]. In contrast, heterogeneous catalysis simplifies catalyst separation and recycling by enabling the use of straightforward centrifugation and filtration techniques and allows to convert substrates to products under beneficial economic and environmental conditions. In spite of these great advances in the heterogeneous aerobic oxidation area, there are still other drawbacks in most heterogeneously aerobic oxidation protocols including the use of organic solvents, expensive metal complexes, basic additives, high temperature and pressure of air/O2 have been reported. Therefore, the discovery of simple and practical oxidations of alcohols to corresponding carbonyl compounds with high selectivity and activity under atmospheric pressure, mild, and safe conditions remains a challenge in synthetic and industrial chemistry. Water-compatible heterogeneously catalysed organic reactions both in- and on-water modes have provided large benefits in terms of environmental sustainability, because water is abundant, cheap and has inherent properties such as viscosity, non-toxicity, non-flammability, high heat capacity, and polarity with the benefit of heterogeneous catalysts including simple handling and easy recoverability [20–23]. Although several efforts have been devoted to the development of water-compatible heterogeneous catalysts, further improvements on heterogeneous water-compatible catalysts able to maintain high activity and stability (no leaching of active species) under aqueous conditions is still a challenging task in green chemistry. Ionic liquids (ILs) are a unique class of strongly ionic materials having negligible volatility. They possess non-flammable nature, high thermal, mechanical and electrochemical stability [24–28]. Combined with their ability to be functionalized and to introduce different cations and anions, the possibility of fine-tuning physico-chemical properties of ILs such as hydrophobicity, solubility, catalytic activity, conductivity, etc is remarkable. To date, considerable attention has been paid on various aspect of ILs including reaction media, catalysis, synthesis, extraction, energy, nanomaterials, and sensing applications [29–32]. However, these materials are fairly costly and their high viscosity and low mass transport, besides some toxicological aspects, are conflicting for widespread practical applications. Recently, ionic liquids immobilized on various porous materials have drawn increasing attention in order to improve their feasibility, recyclability, separation as well as the enhancement of mass transport [33–40]. Although significant progress has been made in the immobilization of ILs, several challenges still need to be addressed including low ionic liquids loading on the support, requirement of an additional functionalization step to interact with the surface of support and poor recyclability due to the weak interactions ILs/solid support and leaching from the carrier upon prolonged reaction times at high temperatures. Considering higher atom economy and more sustainable chemical processes, we have attempted to overcome these problems by simple functionalization and combination of tungstic acid and imidazolium-based siloxane precursor via self-condensation of hydrolysable trialkoxysilyl groups leading to new mesoporous organic-inorganic hybrid materials (PMO-IL-WO4 2 -) containing a high amount of ILs without further modification. Due to the stoichiometric reactions between imidazolium-based organosilane and tungstic acid, strong electrostatic bonding between the cationic surface and tungstate anion takes place and the resulting PMO-IL-WO4 2 - nanohybrid material has a highly robust structure with high thermal and operational stability, an important key factor for lifetime of reusable catalysts. In continuation of our previous efforts to design and develop new immobilized catalysts for organic transformations [41–46], herein we report the synthesis, structural and chemical characterization of a aqueous-compatible solid hybrid material, PMO-IL-WO4 2- with unique charged surface properties which combine a tungstic acid and a zwitterionic organosilane. PMO-IL-WO4 2- was employed as a novel, water-friendly and reusable catalyst for the selective aerobic oxidation of a broad range of primary and secondary alcohols. Experimental General remarks Reagents were purchased from the suppliers and used without further purification. NMR spectra in solution were recorded by using a Bruker DPX 400 spectrometer. Solid-state 13C and 29Si NMR measurements were performed by using a 500 MHz Bruker Avance III widebore NMR spectrometer (Bruker BioSpin GmbH, Rheinstetten, Germany) under cross polarization conditions with a spinning frequency of 11000 Hz. Elemental analyses were performed with an Elementar Vario Micro Cube (Elementar Analysensysteme GmbH, Langenselbold, Germany). An air condenser (FindenserTM, SUPER air condenser, Radleys) was employed in the catalytic reactions instead of a water condenser. Textural properties of the synthesized material were measured by nitrogen physisorption measurements carried out at 77 K using a Micromeritics ASAP 2000 instrument (Micromeritics, Norcross, GA, USA). The specific surface area was calculated using the BET (Brunauer-Emmet-Teller) equation, while pore volume (VBJH) and pore size distributions (DBJH) were obtained by the BJH method (Barrett, Joyner, and Halenda) from the N2 adsorption branch. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns were recorded on a Bruker-AXS diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ =1.5409 Å). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed using a NETZSCH STA 409 PC/PG instrument (NETZSCH-Gerätebau GmbH, Selb, Germany) at scan rates of 10°C. min-1, with typically 5 mg sample in the temperature range from 20 to 900 °C under N2 atmosphere. The scanning electron microscope (SEM) images were taken on a Jeol JSM 6490 LA field emission device with an acceleration voltage of 15 kV (JEOL Ltd., Tokyo, Japan). The infrared spectrum was recorded using with a Perkin Elmer FT-ATR-IR 1000 spectrometer (PerkinElmer, Inc., Massachusetts, United States) containing a diamond coated ZnSe-window. Synthesis of N-(3-propyltriethoxysilane) imidazole A suspension of NaH (1.45 g, 60 mmol) in a 30 mL dry tetrahydrofuran (THF) in a three-neck flask was cooled down to 0 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere. A solution of imidazole (4.1 g, 60 mmol) in 20 mL THF was added dropwise during 2 h. After the complete addition, the ice bath was removed and the mixture was stirred 2 h at room temperature. 3chloropropyltrimethoxysilane (15.65 g, 65 mmol) was then added to the mixture followed by reflux overnight. The solvent was removed under vacuum and then 50 mL dichloromethane were added. The precipitate was filtered under nitrogen atmosphere. The product was then separated by distillation at 125 °C under vacuum. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 0.55 (t, 2 H), 1.17 (t, J =7.5 Hz, 9 H), 1.86 (m, 2 H), 3.53 (q, J =7.4 Hz, 6 H), 3.90 (m, 4 H), 6.89(s, 1 H), 7.02 (s, 1 H), and 7.45(s, 1 H). 13CNMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ 6.3, 18.9, 24.8, 49.2, 50.7, 118.8, 129.5, and 137.3. -(1-(3-(triethoxysilyl)propyl)-1H-imidazol-3-ium-3-yl)propane-1-sulfonate N-(3-propyltriethoxysilane)imidazole (10 mmol, 2.73 g) was dissolved in 10 mL dry acetonitrile and was placed in ice- water bath. While it was stirred vigorously, 1,3-propane sulfone (10 mmol, 1.22 g) was added dropwise to the solution. After 30 minutes of stirring, the ice-water bath was removed and the reaction continued under reflux for 8 h. Evaporation of the solvent under reduced pressure resulted in a white solid washing with diethyl ether, while drying under vacuum resulted in quantitative yield of 3-(1-(3-(triethoxysilyl)propyl)-1H-imidazol-3-ium-3-yl)propane-1-sulfonate. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 9.93 (s, 1H, NCHN), 7.70 (s, 1 H), 7.67 (s, 1 H), 4.01-3.80 (m, 4H, NCH2), 3.78 (q, J =7.5 Hz, 6H, OCH2), 2.86 (t, J =7.5 Hz, 2H, SCH2), 2.15 (m, 2H, CH2), 1.72 (m, 2H, CH2), 1.23 (t, J=7.5 Hz, 9H, OCH2CH3), 0.57. 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 134.1, 123.6, 120.3, 59.2, 51.1, 48.6, 47.1, 21.8, 19.0, 7.9. Synthesis of PMO-IL-WO4 2- materials 3-(1- (3triethoxysilyl)propyl)-1H-imidazol-3-ium-3-yl)propane-1-sulfonate (10 mmol, 3.95 g) was added to 10 mL of dry acetonitrile, then tungstic acid (H2WO4) (5 mmol 1.25 g) was added to the solution under vigorous stirring at room temperature for 3 h. Fast hydrolysis and self-condensation of organo-siloxane moiety leads to the formation of acidic ionic liquid silica network with inorganic tungstate anions in the material. The resulted yellow solid was filtered and washed with acetonitrile and dried under vacuum. Elemental analysis: found C: 26.95%, N: 6.35%, S: 7.40% and H: 4.55%. 29Si CP-MAS NMR (99 MHz) δ -61.05 (T1, R-Si(OSi)1(OR)2), -70.47 (T2, R-Si(OSi)2(OR)1), -79.56 (T3, R-Si(OSi)3). 13C CP-MAS NMR (126 MHz) δ 140.81, 124.07, 49.51, 27.84, 15.07, 4.61. General procedure for selective aerobic oxidation of alcohols using PMO-IL-WO4 2- materials A 25 mL single-necked round bottomed flask equipped with a condenser was charged with alcohol (10 mmol) and water (5 mL) were added and stirred. PMO -IL-WO4 2- (0.01 g) was then added to the above solution and the resulting mixture was stirred at 90 °C under atmospheric air pressure for the required time. The progress of the reaction was monitored by TLC and/or gas chromatography using standard addition method. After completion of the reaction, the mixture was allowed to cool down to room temperature and the catalyst was successfully filtrated, washed with ethyl acetate (2 x 10 mL) and dried under vacuum for the next run. Then, the filtrate was first washed with water, dried over magnesium sulfate, and the solvent concentrated with evaporation under vacuum to give the corresponding carbonyl compounds. Results and discussion Material synthesis and characterization In this work, an imidazolium sulfonate silane precursor, 3-(1-(3-(triethoxysilyl)propyl)-1H-imidazol-3-ium-3-yl)propane-1-sulfonate was synthesized from imidazole (Scheme 1 ). Firstly, the propyl silane chain was introduced to the imidazole ring via silanization with 3-choloropropyltrimethoxy silane, further reacted with 1,3-propanesultone to form silylated imidazolium sulfonate-based ionic liquid precursor in a quaternizing proccess. Finally, hydrolysis and self-condensation of the silylated imidazolium sulfonate ionic liquid by tungstic acid (acting as a Brönsted acid catalyst for the construction of the siloxan network) resulted into the new mesoporous organic-inorganic hybrid materials containing tungstate ion inside the channels of a brönsted acidic imidazolium-based ionic liquid framework (PMO-IL-WO4 2-). The structural and chemical properties of the hybrid material PMO-IL-WO4 2- were investigated by solid-state NMR and FT-IR spectroscopy, scanning electron microscopy, thermogravimetric and elemental analysis. N2 physisorption analysis of the organic-inorganic hybrid materials (PMO-IL-WO4 2-) was performed to study surface porosity, showing III type isotherm curves according to IUPAC classification (not shown) with a BET surface area of 96 m2 g-1, a pore volume of 0.41 mL g-1 and a narrow pore size distribution centered around 18.6 nm, indicating mesostructuration in PMO-IL-WO4 2 - hybrid materials. Solid state NMR spectra provided convincing evidences that the imidazolium inclusion into PMO-IL-WO4 2 - was accomplished. In the solid-state 29Si NMR spectrum of PMO-IL-WO4 2 -, there are the three signals exclusively in the range of δ=-60 to -80 ppm, assigned to Ti peaks. Ti corresponds to R–Si (–OSi)i–OR(3−i) structures, related to self-condensation reactions and siloxane network formation. Three T peaks at -61.05, -70.47, -79.56 ppm respectively corresponds to T3, T2, T1 with a higher proportion in T2 species represented linear siloxane sequences. Two overlapping T1signals in the region -56.53 and -54.38 could be attributed to Si-OEt and Si-OH, respectively. Similarly, two overlapping peaks appeared for T3. Moreover, the absence of Qi signals, corresponding to four Si-O bridges witnessed about no C-Si bond cleavage taking place during the self-condensation process (Fig. 1 ). Incorporation of organic moieties into the silica framework was also confirmed by 13C CP-MAS NMR spectra. It showed the presence of five resonances at 140.81, 124.07, 49.51, 27.84, 15.07, and 4.61 ppm. Broad signals appeared to overlap to each other in aliphatic region at 49.51, 27.84, and15.07 ppm assigned to methyl and methylene carbon atoms of propyl units. The signal at 4.61 ppm could be assigned to methylene carbon atom attached to silicon atom (Si-CH2-). Carbon atoms of imidazolium ring were found at 124.07 ppm. The imidazolium carbon (NCN) resonance signal appears at 140.81 ppm (Fig. 1). This analysis confirms successful incorporation of imidazolium rings into the mesoporous network. Fig. 2 shows FT-IR spectrum of PMO-IL-WO4 2-. The three bands present at 1448, 1183, 1040 cm-1 were correspondingly assigned to S = O asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations and S-O stretching vibrations of propyl sulfonic acid, respectively. SO2 bending vibrations were observed at 732 cm-1. The band observed at 787 cm-1 is assigned to C-S stretching vibrations. Four bands at 789, 890, 975 cm-1were respectively attributed to W-O-W, W-O, W = O, stretching vibrations of tungstate anion. A broad band at 3470 cm-1 corresponds to O-H stretching vibrations of hydroxyl groups of HPA and sulfonic acid. =C-H stretching band (3076 cm-1), C = C- stretching band (1608cm-1), -C = N stretching vibrations (1653 cm-1) and = C–H bending bands (656 cm-1) could also be observed for imidazolium rings. Three absorbances at 2870-2945 cm-1 were assigned to stretching vibrations of–C-H methylene groups of the alkyl chain. The typical O-Si-O stretching vibration could be seen at 1083 cm-1. These observations indicate the incorporation of organic moieties into the silica framework with tungstate anion via self-condensation and hydrolysis of silyl ethoxy groups. Thermal stability of PMO-IL-WO4 2- hybrid materials was subsequently studied using thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) as shown in Fig. 3 . The analysis was performed from room temperature to 910 °C. The first weight loss of about 8% occurred in the temperature range of 80-130 °C, due to the released of physisorbed solvents from the pores. The main weight loss of about 32% between 530-630 °C could be attributed to the thermal decomposition of the hybrid materials itself. This result indicates that the hybrid material has a thermal stability up to 530 °C. Furthermore, elemental analyses results are another proof for the formation of the desired PMO-IL-WO4 2- hybrid materials. The percentage of carbon, hydrogen, nitrogen and sulfur in the composition of PMO-IL-WO4 2- hybrid materials was determined to be C: 26.95%, N: 6.35%, S: 7.40% and H: 4.55%, all confirmed using elemental analysis. SEM images of PMO-IL-WO4 2- (Fig. 4 ) revealed the formation of nano-sized materials and a generally amorphous morphology with irregular blocks and agglomerated particles. Catalytic studies PMO-IL-WO4 2- hybrid materials with accessible sulfonic acid and redox properties of tungstate anions into the channels were expected to exhibit potentially cooperative catalytic behavior for alcohol oxidations. The results of catalyst evaluation study for aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol (10 mmol) as model under several reaction conditions are summarized in Table 1 . Firstly, the aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol using molecular oxygen from air (1 atm) in the presence of 0.02 gr of PMO-IL-WO4 2- as catalyst was tested in acetonitrile (5 mL) at room temperature. The aerobic oxidation sluggishly proceeded under these conditions and 20% of benzaldehyde was obtained only after 24 h (Table 1, entry 1). A similar reaction at 80 °C smoothly produced a significant change in the conversion to afford 71% benzaldehyde as unique product (Table 1, entry2). When aerobic oxidation reaction was performed in protic polar solvents including acetic acid and water, higher benzaldehyde yields were obtained (Table 1, entries 3-14), implying the hydrophilic nature of the material influenced the catalytic performance in protic solvents. The same reaction carried out under solventless conditions provided only moderate benzaldehyde conversion (Table 1, entry 15). Further optimizations for reaction times and temperatures were investigated. Benzaldehyde yields were improved when increasing the reaction temperature to 90 °C (up to 96%, Table 1, entry 9). However higher reaction temperatures, for instance 100 °C and over, had little effect probably due to a lower diffusivity of oxygen within the reaction media. Most importantly, selectivity for benzaldehyde was reduced due to over-oxidation to benzoic acid (Table 1, entries 12 &13). The effect of amount of catalyst on the aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde was subsequently studied by varying the amount 0.008-0.02 gr. 0.01 gr of catalyst was sufficient to reach the highest conversion and selectivity. However, excessive amount of catalyst reduced the yield of benzaldehyde because of further oxidation to benzoic acid (Table 1, entry 14). In addition, a decrease in yield of benzaldehyde was observed when the amount of catalyst was reduced to 0.008 g and below (entry 10). The aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol was very slow in the absence of catalyst even after 24 h (Table 1, entry 16). Investigation of various conditions and the impact of reaction solvent, time, temperature and amount of catalyst revealed that they played important roles to achieve excellent conversion and selectivity, with optimum conditions found in entry 9, Table 1. Only 30% yield of benzaldehyde was obtained after 24 h at 90 °C when the reaction was carried out in the presence of unsupported homogeneous tungstic acid, indicating that a phase transfer catalyst is probably required to make organic-inorganic phase compatibility (entry17). IL-SO3- also exhibited very low catalytic activity, with only 12% yield of benzaldehyde obtained after 24 h (Table 1, entry 18). These results indicate the important role of tungstate ions on the ionic support surface for efficient aerobic oxidation reactions. Moreover, to study the cooperative effect of imidazolium ionic liquid framework and tungstate ion, the catalytic activity of was compared with that of neat sulfonated phenylene-bridge PMO (PMO-SO3H) produced in our previous work and a mixture of them and tungstic acid. Both conditions were not good in the catalytic aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol (Table 1, entries 19&20). To assess the nature of the catalysis and leaching of active species from the support, a hot filtration test was performed during the aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol under optimized conditions. The catalyst was removed by hot filtration after 4 h and the filtrate system was futher left to react after catalyst removal for 6 h and 24 h. No aerobic oxidation progress was observed (monitored by GC), indicating that no catalytically active species remained in the filtrate. The result confirmed the strong incorporation and interaction of tungstate and imidazolium containing sulfonic acid in the organosilica network not only could suppress leaching of active species, but also could enhance the catalytic activity of the catalyst via synergistic and cooperative effects. Fig. 5 also shows the reaction profile of benzyl alcohol (10 mmol) aerobic oxidation in the presence of 0.01 g of PMO-IL-WO4 2- catalyst and 10 mL of water at 90 °C. Based on reaction rate, only a short induction period was observed and complete conversion was reached after 12 h. As can be seen in the reaction profile, no significant improvement was observed in the conversion by increasing reaction time to 14 h. The scope and applicability of PMO-IL-WO4 2- was further studied in the aerobic oxidation of primary and secondary alcohols under optimized conditions. Notably, PMO-IL-WO4 2- exhibited an excellent performance in the aerobic oxidation of various types of aliphatic and benzylic alcohols to the corresponding carbonyl compounds in high selectivity. Primary benzylic alcohols selectively underwent aerobic oxidation to their corresponding aldehydes, without over oxidation to the respective carboxylic acids (Table 2 , entries 1-6). Secondary benzylic alcohols for example, 1-pentyl ethanol and 1-(4-methoxyphenyl) ethanol were successfully oxidized to their corresponding ketones in good to excellent yields (Table 2, entries 8-11). Both electron donating and withdrawing substituents on the phenyl ring of benzylic alcohols were simply oxidized to the corresponding carbonyl compounds in high selectivity. Electron donating substituents had slightly beneficial effects on oxidized product yields as compared to electron withdrawing groups. Sterically more hindered alcohols such as diphenylmethanol and ortho substituents on the phenyl ring of benzylic alcohols were also converted to the desired oxidation products in high yields (Table 2, entries 3, 9, and 10). Additionally, aliphatic alcohols either cyclic or acyclic smoothly underwent aerobic oxidation and gave moderate to good yields of respective products (Table 2, entries 12-16). These promising results provided clear evidence that acidity and ionicity of the support could effectively influence the activity and selectivity of the resulted catalyst. Moreover, the number of sulfonic acid sites on the ionic surface of the hybrid material was sufficiently large to have a water-compatible hydrophilic material. Additionally, the hydrophobicity of organic moieties on the surface provided an effective contribution in the diffusion of reactants. All of these hydrophilic/hydrophobic cooperative features have significant impact on performance of the catalytic aerobic oxidation system under environmentally and economically benign conditions. Finally, to evaluate the economic viability of a robust and selective catalyst, we studied the reusability of catalyst in the aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol under the optimized conditions. After the first reaction, the catalyst was separated by simple filtration from the reaction mixture, washed with ethyl acetate, dried, reused for the next reaction run. Noteworthy, the catalyst showed great catalytic activity and selectivity for at least ten reaction cycles under the same conditions as fresh catalyst without any significant loss of catalytic activity for the aqueous aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol, proving that the catalyst is highly stable and simple to recycle (Fig. 6 ). In the last run, atomic absorption spectroscopy (AAS) analysis of the reaction solution confirmed the content of tungsten species in the solution was below of the detection limit, indicating that leaching of the active W system is negligible during the reaction process. Furthermore, the recovered catalyst was characterized by SEM image after ten runs. SEM image revealed that surface morphology of the recycled catalyst showed almost similar structure as compared to the fresh catalyst (Fig. 7 ). In Table 3 , comparison of the efficiency of PMO-IL-WO4 2-catalyst for aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol with some other solid supported catalytic systems is presented. As shown in this Table, PMO-IL-WO4 2 - was found to be more efficient than most solid catalysts studied in literature. Conclusions Tungstate-based ionic liquid hybrid material (PMO-IL-WO4 2 -) has been successfully prepared by introduction of a 3-propyl-1-sulfonate side chain to imidazole silane-based precursors followed by a self-assembly condensation reaction without using any support or template. FT-IR, TGA, CHNS, solid-state NMR spectroscopy and SEM confirmed the strong interaction between the organic cation and inorganic tungstate anion in the solid material. After complete characterization and structural confirmation, the resulted solid PMO-IL-WO4 2- containing cooperative hydrophobic/hydrophilic surface properties have been utilized as water-compatible catalyst in selective aerobic oxidations of a variety of primary and secondary alcohols. PMO-IL-WO4 2 - constitute an unique class of ionic hybrid materials combining the properties of ionic, redox, and brönsted acid that enable cooperative aerobic oxidation catalysis with the strong ability to control selectivity toward the desired oxidative products. Remarkably, we have developed an eco-friendly, low cost, simple, and feasible system for highly selective aerobic oxidation of variety of alcohols using PMO-IL-WO4 2- catalyst with the advantages of heterogeneous recyclability in water as green media. coredata.dc:description: A Brönsted acidic Ionic Liquid containing tungstate anion functionalized polysiloxane network (PMO-IL-WO4 2 -) was synthesized by simple self-condensation of tungstic acid and zwitterionic organosilane precursor possessing both imidazolium and sulfonate groups. Characterization by scanning electron microscopy (SEM), Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), X-ray powder diffraction (XRD), thermal gravimetric analysis TGA, nitrogen porosimetry, solid-state NMR spectroscopy and elemental analysis confirmed that both imidazolium cation and tungstate anion of zwitterion are successfully incorporated inside the organosilica framework. The catalytic activity of resulting hybrid PMO-IL- WO4 2- material was studied in the selective aerobic oxidation of primary and secondary alcohols using an atmospheric pressure of air in pure water. Due to the ionic liquid-based charged surface containing hydrophilic sulfonic acid and tungstate group, the synergistic hydrophilic/hydrophobic and redox effect of PMO-IL-WO4 2 - as water-friendly catalyst facilitates and enhances the activity and selectivity toward the target oxidative products in water and proved to have a particularly broad substrate scope for reliable aerobic oxidation reaction. Furthermore, the catalyst showed outstanding stability and could be easily separated and reused at least ten reactions run under the same conditions as fresh catalyst without any loss of catalytic activity and product selectivity.
coredata.dc:title: Tungstate ion (WO4 2-) confined in hydrophilic/hydrophobic nanomaterials functionalized brönsted acidic ionic liquid as highly active catalyst in the selective aerobic oxidation of alcohols in water
